data.title: MOVIE GREAT HAL ROACH DIES
data.text:
Hal Roach, a founding father of American motion picture comedy who discovered and helped develop the talents of such superstars of the early cinema as Harold Lloyd, Stan Laurel and Oliver Hardy, died Nov. 2 in California. He was 100.

He died at his home in Bel-Air of pneumonia, a friend, Richard Bann, told the Associated Press.

Mr. Roach, a producer and director, was present at the very beginnings of the American film industry. He started as an extra in a 1912 western and within less than three years had his own production studio. In 1922, he made a short comedy called "Our Gang," initiating a series that would amuse and delight moviegoers for generations. He established a comic partnership that would last for more than three decades when he teamed up Laurel and Hardy in 1927.

Two of his pictures, a 1932 Laurel and Hardy movie called "The Music Box" and a 1936 film in the "Our Gang" series called "Bored of Education," won Academy Awards for best short film.

Advertisement

In 1955, Mr. Roach turned his studio over to his son and retired from the movie business. But he remained on the Hollywood scene and over the years came to be known as a Grand Old Man of American cinema. He was awarded an honorary Oscar in 1984 for an "unparalleled record of distinguished contributions to the motion picture art form."

His 1914 discovery of Harold Lloyd, then working as an extra for Universal Pictures, gave Mr. Roach his first star and enabled him to become the only major rival of Mack Sennett in the production of silent film comedy shorts during the 1920s.

Under Mr. Roach's guidance and over time, Lloyd developed his own cimematic persona. He put on horn-rimmed glasses. He was sincere and soft-spoken, and sometimes a little naive. Yet his character had a bedrock foundation of honor and decency that made him the quintessential boy-next-door. During the 1920s Lloyd would surpass Charlie Chaplin in box office popularity, specializing in situations where he placed himself in extreme and bizarre physical danger, but always escaped.

Advertisement

In putting Laurel and Hardy together, Mr. Roach created what would become the first major comic partnership in motion picture history, and one that set the stage for others that followed, such as Bud Abbott and Lou Costello, Bob Hope and Bing Crosby and Dean Martin and Jerry Lewis. The two actors in Mr. Roach's team complemented each other superbly. Laurel, an Englishman who came to the United States with the same vaudeville troupe as Chaplin, was a weak and whining simpleton. Hardy, a native Georgian who began his show business career as a singer and bit player, was a pompous, self-important lout and bully.

Typically, their films followed a story line in which a single incident would escalate to a level of catastrophic dimensions, invariably with the help of the stupidity, vengefulness and pig-headedness of the two comedians.

From 1927 to 1929, Laurel and Hardy made 27 silent film shorts for Mr. Roach, and because they had trained for the stage they made an easy transition into sound movies.

Advertisement

Hal Roach was born Jan. 14, 1892, in Elmira, N.Y., where his mother operated a boarding house and his father sold jewelry. He left home for Seattle, intending to visit a relative, when he was 16, and he never returned. From Seattle, he sailed to Alaska, where he prospected for gold, then drove teams of horses and mules along a road under construction between Valdez and Fairbanks.

Later he drifted south to Los Angeles. He was a construction superintendent working on horseback in the Mojave Desert when in 1912 he noticed a newspaper advertisement seeking extras to play motion picture cowboys at Universal Studios. Mr. Roach put on his boots and spurs, his bandanna and Stetson hat, went to Universal and got the job. "They offered me a dollar and lunch, two sandwiches and a banana. But all I really wanted was to see how films were made," he recalled decades later.

In his first day on the job, Mr. Roach noticed that the wheel and ball on a roulette wheel were going in the same direction in a film sequence of a gambling hall scene. He pointed out the mistake to the director and was promptly hired as a technical adviser at $5 a day.

Advertisement

With funds saved from this compensation and a small inheritance, Mr. Roach opened his own studio. He sold his first film with Harold Lloyd for $850.

It was almost by accident that Mr. Roach became the creator of the "Our Gang" films. As he recalled some years later, he was sitting in his office one day when he opened a window to get some fresh air:

" . . . there were about a half dozen kids playing out there with some scraps of wood. One little kid claims a bigger kid has got his stick, and he's trying to get the other kids to back him in this argument.

"Now you know in the next block they're all gonna throw these sticks away, but watching them you'd think their lives depended on who got that stick. And I spent 15 minutes waiting to find out how it turned out. I thought, 'Why? These are just kids doing the things that kids do.' So I said to myself, 'I'll make a comedy about regular kids doing the things that regular kids do.'"

Advertisement

The first of those films was a smashing success, and there would be dozens more each year throughout the 1920s and into the 1930s. By 1938, when Mr. Roach sold the series to MGM, the films had become one of the most famous series in motion picture history.

Three years later Mr. Roach's film-making career was interrupted by the U.S. entry into World War II. He served as a major in the Army Signal Corps during the war, then returned to Hollywood after the war to resume operation of his studio, making productions for both the movies and television until he sold the studio to his son, Hal Roach Jr.

His first wife, Marguerite O. Roach, died in 1941. Hal Roach Jr. died in 1972, and their daughter, Margaret, also preceded her father in death.

Mr. Roach also was preceded in death by his second wife, Lucille. They had three daughters.

STANLEY R. DURKEE

Broker

Stanley Robbins Durkee, 84, a retired senior partner in the Washington brokerage of Johnston Lemon & Co. Inc., died of pneumonia Nov. 1 at Suburban Hospital. He lived in Bethesda.

Mr. Durkee was born in Nova Scotia and grew up in Washington. He was a 1925 graduate of Central High School and a 1929 graduate of Amherst College, where he belonged to the Delta Epsilon fraternity.

He was a broker on Wall Street and a securities analyst with a New York bank from 1929 to 1937, when he returned here and joined Johnston Lemon. He joined the firm as a statistician, then was appoined sales manager in 1946 after World War II Navy service. He became a general partner in 1955 and retired as a senior partner in 1982.

Mr. Durkee had taught American University courses in securities analysis at the Pentagon in the mid-1950s. He had served as president of the Amherst Club of Washington and was a member of the University Club, the Belle Haven Country Club and the Mayflower Society of Washington.

Advertisement

His first wife, the former Marian S. McDonald, whom he married in 1937, died in 1970. Six years later, he married Mary Catherine Daugherty. She died in 1985.

Survivors include two sons from his first marriage, Stanley Bradford Durkee of Bethesda and Donald Blanchard Durkee of Sterling; a granddaughter; and a stepgrandson.

WILLIS W. ATWELL

Government Official

Willis Whitney Atwell, 83, a retired official of the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services who chaired the Montgomery County Commission on Aging from 1982 to 1985, died Oct. 30 at Holy Cross Hospital. He had lung cancer.

Mr. Atwell, a Rockville resident, moved here from his native Michigan in 1964. He worked for the American Association of Retired Persons before joining what was then the Department of Health, Education and Welfare in 1969.

Advertisement

From 1969 to 1972, he was a deputy commissioner on aging at HEW, and he helped organize the 1971 White House Conference on Aging. He retired from the federal government in 1982 as associate commissioner for program development in the administration on aging in the Health and Human Services Department's human development services office.

Mr. Atwell, a 1930 graduate of Michigan State University, had worked in community organizations in Grand Rapids, Mich., before moving here. He was the author of "Do You Know -- An Illustrated History of Michigan," published by the Booth newspapers.

He was a member of St. Mary Magdalene Episcopal Church in Wheaton, the Episcopal Society for Ministry in Aging and the National Inter-Faith Coalition on Aging.

Survivors include his wife of 55 years, Mary P. Atwell, of Rockville; three sons, Willis Atwell Jr. of Grandville, Mich., Richard P. Atwell of Kalamazoo, Mich., and Charles H. Atwell of Silver Spring; a daughter, Mary E. Atwell of Weare, N.H.; and six grandchildren.

ALBERT B. DEWEY

CIA Official

Albert B. Dewey, 63, a retired official of the Central Intelligence Agency, where he specialized in the use of computers in information management, died of cancer Oct. 29 at Fauquier Hospital in Warrenton, Va.

A resident of The Plains, Va., Mr. Dewey was born in Chicago and grew up in Washington. He graduated from St. Lawrence University and received a master's degree in mathematics from Syracuse University. He served in the Army during the Korean War.

He began his career with the CIA in the late 1950s, and he retired in the late 1970s.

Mr. Dewey was the treasurer and a member of the vestry at Grace Episcopal Church in The Plains.

His marriage to Eleanor Dewey ended in divorce.

Survivors include his wife of 19 years, Alice R. Dewey of The Plains; three children of his first marriage, Albert E. Dewey III of Luray, Va., Gwendolyn Sanchez of Miami and John Dewey of Dallas; a brother, Chauncey F. Dewey of Chevy Chase; and four grandchildren.

WILLIAM STADLER

Machinist

William Stadler, 89, a retired machinist and precision instrument maker who worked at the National Bureau of Standards from 1948 to 1965, died of pneumonia Oct. 31 at Suburban Hospital. He lived at Friends House in Sandy Spring.

Mr. Stadler was born in Workerszell, Bavaria. He came to the United States in 1927 and lived in New York until 1936, when he moved to Washington to work at the Washington Navy Yard.

Mr. Stadler was a Mason and a member of German organizations that included the Arminius Social Club, Concord Club, Washington Saengerbund, Schlaraffia Washingtonia and the Washingtonia Schuhplatter Club.

Survivors include his wife of 63 years, Josephine Stadler of Sandy Spring; two daughters, Christine S. Tucker of Annapolis and Louis S. Meyer of Washington; two brothers, Ludwig Stadler of Workerszell, and Rupert Stadler of Eichstaett, Bavaria; and five grandchildren.

JOE R. MOTHERAL

AID Official

Joe R. Motheral, 78, a retired Agency for International Development official and former consultant, died of liver cancer Oct. 30 at his home in McLean.

Dr. Motheral, a native of Lockhart, Tex., earned bachelor's and master's degrees at Texas A&M University and a doctorate in agricultural economics and sociology at the University of Wisconsin. He served with the Navy in the Pacific during World War II.

He served on the faculty of Texas A&M for 11 years before coming here and joining the Agriculture Department in 1952. He worked there until 1957 when he began a three-year tour as a Harvard University agricultural economics adviser to the Pakistan Planning Commssion and the Harvard Pakistan Project.

He worked for the World Bank here from 1960 to 1962, then worked for AID until retiring in 1971 as chief of its agricultural division in Afghanistan. He also had worked for AID in Pakistan and South Korea. He was a consulant to the United Nations and various foreign governments until retiring again in 1979.

Dr. Motheral's professional memberships included the American Agricultural Economics Association and the American Rural Sociologist Society. He was a recipient of South Korea's Order of Civil Merit.

Survivors include his wife of 58 years, the former Verna Toland, of McLean; a son, Joe, of Taipei, Taiwan; three sisters; a brother; three grandchildren; and a great-grandson.

MARTIN H. ARMSTRONG

Foreign Service Officer

Martin H. Armstrong, 72, a retired Foreign Service officer, died Oct. 29 at Woodbine Nursing Home in Falls Church. He had Parkinson's disease.

Mr. Armstrong, who lived in Washington, was born in Seattle. He graduated from Georgetown University, and during World War II he served in the Navy as an aviator in the Atlantic. He retired from the Navy Reserve as a lieutenant commander in 1967.

He began his Foreign Service career in Hamburg, in 1951. Later assignments included service in Dacca, East Pakistan; Karachi, Pakistan; Belgrade, Washington, Nepal and Cairo, where he was consul during the 1967 Arab-Israeli War. He received a Meritorious Service Award for his service there. He retired from the Foreign Service on disability in 1980 and returned to Washington after serving in Paris.

Survivors include his wife, Josette Armstrong of Paris; and a daughter, Tina Bezzola of Geneva.

TIMOTHY J. CASEY JR.

Home Builder

Timothy J. Casey Jr., 60, a home builder who began his company, T.J. Casey Inc., 22 years ago, died of pneumonia Nov. 2 at Suburban Hospital. He lived in Potomac.

Mr. Casey was born in Washington. He was a graduate of Gonzaga College High School, Georgetown University and the American University law school. He served in the Army in West Germany during the Korean War.

Before he went into homebuilding, he operated a steamship excursion company in New York for seven years.

He was a member of the Knights of Columbus and Our Lady of Mercy Catholic Church in Potomac.

Survivors include his wife, Mary Rosetta Casey, and two children, John and Timothy J. Casey III, all of Potomac.

MARY R. HORN

Secretary

Mary R. Horn, 71, a retired secretary, died of cancer Oct. 23 at Sibley Memorial Hospital.

Mrs. Horn, who lived in Washington, was born in Mingo Junction, Ohio. She moved to this area during World War II.

During the 1970s and early 1980s she was a secretary for the Prince George's County Department of Health and in the athletic and engineering departments of the University of Maryland.

She was a member of St. Mary's Catholic Church in Landover Hills.

Her marriage to Joseph Horn ended in divorce.

Survivors include a son, Christian L. Horn of Laurel; a brother, Anthony Belardine of Mingo Junction; and two grandchildren.
